moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e3 Bb4 5. Qc2 O-O 6. Nd5 a5 7. a3 Bc5 8. Ng5
comment:
This attempt to refute the black opening strategy at once does not look
particularly convincing. Much better is further quiet development, e.g.:

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e3 Bb4 5. Qc2 O-O 6. Nd5 a5 7. a3 Bc5 8. Ng5 g6 9. Nxf6+ Qxf6 10. Ne4 Qe7 11. b3 Ba7
comment:
Not letting the bishop be exchanged. Although it
did not do much of anything in the actual game, some variations later proved
this decision has been right.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e3 Bb4 5. Qc2 O-O 6. Nd5 a5 7. a3 Bc5 8. Ng5 g6 9. Nxf6+ Qxf6 10. Ne4 Qe7 11. b3 Ba7 12. Bb2
1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e3 Bb4 5. Qc2 O-O 6. Nd5 a5 7. a3 Bc5 8. Ng5 g6 9. Nxf6+ Qxf6 10. Ne4 Qe7 11. b3 Ba7 12. Bb2 d6 13. Ng3
comment:
A pure waiting move.
Black does not want to make any decisive moves before white has castled. Early
pawn moves on the king side could prove verydangerous indeed, should white
later decide to castle long.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e3 Bb4 5. Qc2 O-O 6. Nd5 a5 7. a3 Bc5 8. Ng5 g6 9. Nxf6+ Qxf6 10. Ne4 Qe7 11. b3 Ba7 12. Bb2 d6 13. Ng3 f5 14. Be2 Be6
comment: ?! Is risky and prematured, although white has to play precisely.
